introduction.p: In this activity, we explore the relationships among the errors generated by left, right, midpoint, and trapezoid approximations to the definite integral \int_1^2 \frac{1}{x^2} \, dx.

statement.p: Which rule consistently over-estimates the exact value of the definite integral? Which rule consistently under-estimates the definite integral?

hint.p: Which estimate is larger than the true value of the definite integral?

answer.p: The trapezoid rule overestimates; the midpoint rule underestimates.

solution.p: From the errors in comparision to the known exact value, we see that the trapezoid rule overestimates this definite integral and the midpoint rule underestimates this definite integral.

statement.p: What behavior(s) of the function f(x) = \frac{1}{x^2} lead to your observations in (d)?

hint.p: Note that how the curve bends makes a big difference in whether the trapezoid rule over- or under-estimates the value of the definite integral.

solution.p: The graph of the function given by f(x) = \dfrac{1}{x^2} is concave up on the interval [1, 2]. Because of this fact, we can see graphically that the line forming the top of each trapezoid lies fully above the curve, and thus the trapezoid rule overestimates the true value of the definite integral. Later in this section we'll see graphically why this concavity makes the midpoint rule an underestimate.
